Title: Adding polynomials
Description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

Title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials
Description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).

Title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
Description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

Title: Adding fractions with different signs
Description: Use a number line to add fractions with different signs.

Title: Adding fractions word problem: paint
Description: Sal solves a word problem by adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

Title: Adding polynomials (Hindi)
Description: Anmol simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

Title: Adding & subtracting multiple polynomials (Hindi)
Description: Anmol simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: x+2y=6 & 4x-2y=14
Description: Learn to use elimination to solve the system of equations x + 2y = 6 and 4x - 2y = 14.

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: -3y+4x=11 & y+2x=13
Description: Sal solves the system of equations -3y + 4x = 11 and y + 2x = 13 using elimination.

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: 2x-y=14 & -6x+3y=-42
Description: Sal solves the system of equations 2x - y = 14 and -6x + 3y = -42 using elimination.

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: Sum/difference of numbers
Description: Sal finds two numbers that sum to 70 and have a difference of 24.

Title: Linear equations 1
Description: equations of the form AX=B

Title: Linear equations 2
Description: solving equations of the form AX+B=C

Title: Linear equations 3
Description: Linear equations with multiple variable and constant terms

Title: Linear equations 4
Description: Solving linear equations with variable expressions in the denominators of fractions

Title: Factoring binomials: common factor
Description: Sal factors 8x²y+12xy² as (4xy)(2x+3y) by taking out the greatest common factor.

Title: Systems of equations with substitution: shelves
Description: Sal solves a system of equations to figure out how long a couple of different shelves will be.

Title: Vertical angles
Description: By using our knowledge of supplementary, adjacent, and vertical angles, we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

Title: Angles, parallel lines, & transversals
Description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

Title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof (Hindi)
Description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

Title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof: visualisation (Hindi)
Description: See how the interior angles of a triangle when together put up, sum up to form a straight angle. This shows us that the sum of three interior angles of a triangle is 180 degrees.

Title: Angles, parallel lines, & transversals (Hindi)
Description: Learn about parallel lines, transversals, and the angles they form.

Title: Non-congruent shapes & transformations
Description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are not congruent by showing it's not possible to map one onto the other using rigid transformations.

Title: Percent word problem: guavas
Description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.

Title: Another Pythagorean theorem proof
Description: Visually proving the Pythagorean Theorem

Title: Linear function example: spending money
Description: Sal solves an interesting application problem using a linear model.

Title: Two-step equation word problem: garden
Description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!

Title: Approximating square roots to hundredths
Description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

Title: Approximating square roots
Description: Learn how to find the approximate values of square roots. The examples used in this video are √32, √55, and √123. The technique used is to compare the squares of whole numbers to the number we're taking the square root of.

Title: Approximating square roots to hundredths (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

Title: Approximating with powers of 10
Description: Learn how to approximate how much larger the world population was than the US population in 2014.

Title: Area of composite shapes
Description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

Title: Multiplying binomials: area model
Description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is x+2 and width is x+3.

Title: Multiplying monomials by polynomials: area model
Description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is 4 and width is x²+3x+2.

Title: Area of a circle
Description: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared (A = π r²). Learn how to use this formula to find the area of a circle when given the diameter.

Title: Area of kites
Description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.

Title: Area of trapezoids
Description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h. Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

Title: Use Pythagorean theorem to find area of an isosceles triangle
Description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find area of an isosceles triangle.

Title: Area of composite shapes (Hindi)
Description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

Title: Area of inscribed equilateral triangle (Hindi)
Description: A worked example of finding the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed within a circle who's area is known. This video uses Heron's formula and some trigonometry.

Title: Area of inscribed equilateral triangle
Description: A worked example of finding the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed within a circle who's area is known. This video uses Heron's formula and some trigonometry.

Title: Area of kites (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.

Title: Area of parallelogram (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to find the area of a parallelogram.

Title: Area of a shaded region
Description: Here's a fun one: find the area of a shaded region where you first determine the area of a square and then the area of a circle.

Title: Area of trapezium (Hindi)
Description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula, A=(a+b)/2 x h. Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

Title: Area of triangle (Hindi)
Description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

Title: Area of triangle proof (Hindi)
Description: Proof that shows that the area of any triangle is 1/2 b x h.

Title: Associative property of multiplication
Description: Sal regroups numbers to simplify multiplication problems.

Title: Associative law of addition
Description: Associative Law of Addition

Title: Associative law of multiplication
Description: Associative Law of Multiplication

Title: Two-step equation word problem: computers
Description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

Title: Bhaskara's proof of the Pythagorean theorem
Description: An elegant visual proof of the Pythagorean Theorem developed by the 12th century Indian mathematician Bhaskara.

Title: Bringing the set operations together
Description: Sal summarizes the set operations that he has discussed in the previous videos.

Title: Scientific notation word problem: red blood cells
Description: Vampires and math students want to know: How many red blood cells are in the a human body? We can find the answer using scientific notation.

Title: Classifying numbers
Description: Learn how to classify numbers as whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers.

Title: Challenge problem- Perimeter of star (Hindi)
Description: Example problem involving perimeter and area.

Title: Triangle angle challenge problem
Description: Interesting problem finding the sums of particular exterior angles of an irregular pentagon

Title: Solutions to 2-variable equations
Description: The solution of an equation with one variable is a number. How does the solution of a 2-variable equation look like? Well, it is an ordered pair. Learn more about it and how to test solutions to 2-variable equations.

Title: Worked example: solutions to 2-variable equations
Description: How do you check if an ordered pair is a solution to a given equation? You need to plug in the numbers and see what equality results. Watch this video to see a worked example.

Title: Circles glossary (Hindi)
Description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs.

Title: Finding circumference of a circle when given the area
Description: Learn how to find the circumference, the distance around a circle, when given the area.

Title: Classifying quadrilaterals (Hindi)
Description: Anmol classifies quadrilaterals by their properties (such as parallel sides).

Title: Example: All the ways you can flip a coin
Description: Manually going through the combinatorics to determine the probability of an event occuring

Title: Commutative law of addition
Description: Commutative Law of Addition

Title: Commutative law of multiplication
Description: Commutative Law of Multiplication

Title: Comparing Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales
Description: N/A

Title: Comparing linear functions: equation vs. graph
Description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another, and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

Title: Comparing linear functions word problem: climb
Description: Sal is given the formula and a table of values that represent two people climbing a wall, and is asked to determine which one started out higher.

Title: Comparing linear functions: table vs. graph
Description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs, and is asked to determine which graph has the same rate of change as the function represented in the table.

Title: Comparing linear functions word problem: walk
Description: Sal is given a table of values that represents four people walking to school, and is asked to determine which one started out farther from the school.

Title: Comparing linear functions: table vs. graph
Description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs, and is asked to determine which graph increases faster than the function represented in the table.

Title: Comparing linear functions word problem: work
Description: Sal is given a table of values that represents a person walking to work, and is asked to determine which verbal description represents someone starting at the same distance from work.

Title: Rates & proportional relationships: gas mileage
Description: Sal chooses equations that give a faster rate than the relationship given in a table.

Title: Rates & proportional relationships example
Description: Sal compares a rate given in an equation to a rate shown on a graph.

Title: Side lengths after dilation
Description: Sal dilates a shape and then compares the side lengths of the pre-image and image.

Title: Theoretical and experimental probabilities
Description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

Title: Comparing values with calculator
Description: Learn how to compare 22.9% to √0.45 using a calculator.

Title: Complementary & supplementary angles
Description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

Title: Complementary & supplementary angles (Hindi)
Description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

Title: Proofs concerning isosceles triangles
Description: Sal proves that the base angles in isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely, that triangles with congruent base angles are isosceles. He also proves that the perpendicular to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects it.

Title: Geometry proof problem: congruent segments
Description: Sal proves that two pairs of segments are congruent using the ASA and AAS congruence criteria.

Title: Geometry proof problem: midpoint
Description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

Title: Congruent triangles & the SSS postulate/criterion
Description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

Title: Congruent triangles & the SSS criterion (Hindi)
Description: Anmol explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

Title: Solutions to systems of equations: consistent vs. inconsistent
Description: A consistent system of equations has at least one solution, and an inconsistent system has no solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's consistent or inconsistent.

Title: Writing proportional equations from tables
Description: Writing an equation to describe the relationship between the number of scoops in an ice cream cone and the price

Title: Linear functions word problem: iceberg
Description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a melting iceberg, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

Title: Linear functions word problem: paint
Description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a person painting his room, and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

Title: Probability models example: frozen yogurt
Description: Model the probability of a frozen yogurt line having 0, 1, or 2 people in it.

Title: Finding a quadrilateral from its symmetries
Description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0,9) and (3,4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

Title: Construct a right isosceles triangle
Description: Can you build a triangle that is both a right triangle and an isosceles triangle?

Title: Making a scale drawing
Description: An urban planner needs your help in creating a scale drawing. Let's use our knowledge about scale factor, length, and area to assist.

Title: Constructing a scatter plot
Description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

Title: Forming systems of equations with different numbers of solutions
Description: Sal write an equation that along with the equation 4x + 5y = 2 forms a system of equations with infinitely many solutions.

Title: Construct a triangle with constraints
Description: Here's a challenge: in this problem we are given constraints and asked to construct a triangle. It can be done! You'll learn about degenerate triangles, too.

Title: Conversion between metric units
Description: N/A

Title: Converting a fraction to a repeating decimal
Description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

Title: Converting a fraction to a repeating decimal (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

Title: Converting decimals to percents: 0.601
Description: Percents can be written in decimal form. Per-cent means per-100. So, we divide the percent by 100 to get an equivalent decimal. Then, we remove the percent sign (%). For example, 65% can be converted to decimal form by solving 65÷100. So, 65%=0.65. Another way to think of dividing by 100 is moving the ...Show More

Title: Converting decimals to percents: 1.501
Description: Sal converts 1.501 to a percent.

Title: Converting Fahrenheit to Celsius
Description: N/A

Title: Fraction to decimal: 11/25
Description: Sal writes 11/25 as a decimal.

Title: Converting percents to decimals: 59.2%
Description: Decimals can be written in percent form. Per-cent means per-100. So, we multiply the decimal by 100 to get an equivalent percent. Then, we add a percent sign (%). For example, 0.8 can be converted to percent form by solving 0.8✕100. So, 0.8=80%. Another way to think of multiplying by 100 is moving the ...Show More

Title: Converting percents to decimals: 113.9%
Description: Sal converts 113.9% to a decimal by demonstrating how to move the decimal point

Title: Converting repeating decimals to fractions part 2 of 2 (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.363636... and 0.714141414... and 3.257257257... to fractions.

Title: Converting to slope-intercept form
Description: Learn to convert equations like 4x + 2y = -8 into slope-intercept form.

Title: Coordinate plane: graphing points (Hindi)
Description: Anmol graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

Title: Coordinate plane graphing word problem (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

Title: Coordinate plane graphing word problem
Description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

Title: Counting faces and edges of 3D shapes
Description: Sal identifies the faces and edges on various 3D shapes.

Title: Converting repeating decimals to fractions (part 1 of 2)
Description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.77777... and 1.22222... to fractions.

Title: Converting repeating decimals to fractions (part 2 of 2)
Description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.363636... and 0.714141414... and 3.257257257... to fractions.

Title: Volume of rectangles inside rectangles
Description: How many crates can we fit into a boxcar? We'll explain that there's more than one way to solve for the volume in this problem.

Title: Obtaining a function from an equation
Description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. In this video, we obtain a function from an equation. The function represents the same relationship between the quantities in the equation.

Title: Creating an equation with infinitely many solutions (Hindi)
Description: Anmol shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

Title: Creating an equation with no solutions (Hindi)
Description: Anmol shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

Title: Creating a bar graph
Description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

Title: Cube root of a non-perfect cube (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to find the cube root of a non-perfect cube.

Title: Cylinder surface area (Hindi)
Description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

Title: Cylinder volume & surface area
Description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h, and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

Title: Determining rotations
Description: Find the angle of a rotation by considering the source and the image of the rotation.

Title: Defining transformations
Description: Given a description of the effect of a certain transformation, we determine whether that transformation is a translation, a rotation, or a reflection.

Title: Intro to the coordinate plane
Description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.

Title: Describing steps when solving equations (Hindi)
Description: Anmol lists the steps necessary in order to solve a linear equation. This is useful for thinking more strategically about equations.

Title: Subsets of sample spaces
Description: Sal solves an example about subsets.

Title: The meaning of percent
Description: Let's think about what percent really means by looking at a 10 by 10 grid.

Title: Meaning of 109%
Description: Percents are parts per hundred. So, how does this work for percents greater than 100% like 109%?

Title: Translation challenge problem
Description: A translation acting on the coordinate plane takes the point (-169,434) to point (-203, -68). What are the coordinates of the image of point (31, -529) under this translation?

Title: Testing solutions to linear equations
Description: Sal figures out which equation was used to generate a table of x and y values.

Title: Determining reflections
Description: Finding the line of reflection by considering the image and the source of the reflection.

Title: Equations vs. functions
Description: Equations and functions are not the same thing, but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

Title: Difference of squares intro
Description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares, i.e. a²-b², then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

Title: Difference of squares intro (Hindi)
Description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares, i.e. a²-b², then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

Title: Special products of the form (x+a)(x-a)
Description: Sal introduces difference of squares expressions. For example, (x+3)(x-3) is expanded as x²-9.

Title: Dilating points
Description: Dilate points on a grid and coordinate plane when given a scale factor.

Title: Dilations: scale factor
Description: Find the scale factor of a dilation that maps a given figure to another one.

Title: Dilations and properties
Description: What properties of a shape are preserved or not preserved after a dilation?

Title: Dilations intro
Description: An introduction to dilation which is a non-rigid transformation (distance between points is not preserved).

Title: Dimensions of a cube from its volume
Description: Learn how to find the side length of a cube whose volume is 512 cubic centimeters.

Title: Worked example: finding missing monomial side in area model
Description: Sal finds the length of a rectangle whose area is 42xy^3 and whose height is 14xy.

Title: Dimensions of a rectangle from coordinates
Description: Given the vertices of a rectangle, can you find the lengths of the sides?

Title: Intro to direct & inverse variation
Description: Sal explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

Title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation: table
Description: Sal is given a table with a few values of the variables x and y, and determines whether the variables vary directly or inversely.

Title: Distance formula
Description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula, which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

Title: Distributive property exercise examples
Description: You'll be a pro applying the distributive property once you've solved these exercise examples with us.

Title: Dividing a decimal by a power of 10
Description: Sal talks about why moving the decimal point to the left when dividing by a power of 10 makes sense.

Title: Dividing by 2-digits: 7182÷42
Description: Learn to divide 7182÷42. There is no remainder.

Title: Dividing polynomials: long division
Description: Sal divides (x^2-3x+2) by (x-2) and then checks the solution.

Title: Dividing polynomials with remainders
Description: Sal divides (x^3+5x-4) by (x^2-x+1) using long division.

Title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors (example 2)
Description: Sal divides (7x^6+x^3+2x+1) by X^2, and writes the solution as q(x)+r(x)/x^2, where the degree of the remainder, r(x), is less than the degree of x^2.

Title: Dividing polynomials with remainders (Hindi)
Description: Anmol divides (x^3+5x-4) by (x^2-x+1) using long division.

Title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors (example 2) (Hindi)
Description: Anmol divides (7x^6+x^3+2x+1) by X^2, and writes the solution as q(x)+r(x)/x^2, where the degree of the remainder, r(x), is less than the degree of x^2.

Title: Dividing polynomials with remainders: monomial divisors (Hindi)
Description: Anmol divides (18x^4-3x^2+6x-4) by 6x.

Title: Divisibility tests for 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 10
Description: Worked example of basic divisibility tests.

Title: Translating shapes
Description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation, and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

Title: Slope-intercept equation from slope & point
Description: Learn how to find the equation of the line with a slope of -3/4 that goes through the point (0,8).

Title: Slope-intercept equation from two points
Description: Learn how to find the equation of the line that goes through the points (-1, 6) and (5, -4).

Title: Worked example: number of solutions to equations
Description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.

Title: Equation with the variable in the denominator (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.

Title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.

Title: Two-step equations intuition
Description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples, but you can do it!

Title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides
Description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

Title: Equations for proportional relationships
Description: Learn how to write a proportional equation y=kx where k is the so-called "constant of proportionality".

Title: Equations with parentheses (Hindi)
Description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

Title: Equations with variables on both sides: 20-7x=6x-6 (Hindi)
Description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.

Title: Isosceles & equilateral triangles problems
Description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving, by Richard Rusczyk).

Title: Proofs concerning equilateral triangles
Description: Sal proves that the angles of an equilateral triangle are all congruent (and therefore they all measure 60°), and conversely, that triangles with all congruent angles are equilateral.

Title: Factoring difference of squares: analyzing factorization
Description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 16x^2-64 and determines whether they are correct.

Title: Estimating the line of best fit exercise
Description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

Title: Evaluating polynomials
Description: Evaluating 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.

Title: Worked example: evaluating expressions using structure
Description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression, but we don't know the individual variable values.

Title: Worked example: evaluating expressions using structure (more examples)
Description: A few more examples where Sal evaluates expressions with multiple unknown variables.

Title: Evaluating polynomials (Hindi)
Description: Evaluating 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.

Title: Probability with counting outcomes
Description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.

Title: Age word problem: Arman & Diya
Description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?

Title: Age word problem: Imran
Description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years, Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

Title: Equation with the variable in the denominator
Description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.

Title: Age word problem: Ben & William
Description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago, William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?

Title: Estimating with linear regression (linear models)
Description: Use a regression line to make a prediction.

Title: Finding distance with Pythagorean theorem
Description: Sal finds the distance between two points with the Pythagorean theorem.

Title: Dilations: center
Description: Determining the center of dilation, given a figure and its image under a dilation.

Title: Intro to rotational symmetry
Description: Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.

Title: Equation practice with complementary angles
Description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

Title: Equation practice with supplementary angles
Description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

Title: Number of solutions to a system of equations algebraically
Description: Sal solves several examples where he reasons about the number of solutions of systems of equations using algebraic reasoning.

Title: Interpreting graphs of proportional relationships
Description: Learn how to read and understand graphs of proportional relationships

Title: Dividing negative fractions
Description: N/A

Title: One-step addition & subtraction equations: fractions & decimals
Description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

Title: Experimental probability
Description: Based on past experience, we can make reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events.

Title: Modeling with linear equations: snow
Description: Sal uses a linear equation to model the amount of snow on the ground.

Title: Exponent properties 1
Description: When multiplying numbers with common base, add exponents

Title: Exponent properties 2
Description: Exponent Properties 2

Title: Exponent properties 3
Description: Exponent Properties 3

Title: Worked example: Exponent properties
Description: Use exponent properties to simplify a challenging expression.

Title: Exponent properties with products
Description: Learn how to simplify exponents when the numbers are multiplied with each other. We'll learn that (a*b)^c is the same as a^c*b^c, a^c*a^d is same as a^(c+d) and (a^c)^d is equal to a^(c*d). We will also solve examples based on these three properties.

Title: Exponent properties with quotients
Description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video, we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

Title: Exponentiation warmup
Description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

Title: Exponents with negative bases
Description: Learn to what we know about negative numbers to determine how negative bases with exponents are affected and what patterns develop. Also learn how order of operations affect the pattern.

Title: Intro to grouping
Description: Sal introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

Title: Factoring polynomials: common factor (old)
Description: An old video where Sal factors 4x⁴y+8x³y as 4x³y(x+2).

Description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.

Title: Factoring difference of squares: two variables

Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares, like x²-25 or 49x²-y², then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful ...Show More

Description: If we expand (a+b)(a-b) we will get a²-b². Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares, like x²-25 or 49x²-y², then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example, x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful ...Show More

Description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.

Description: A video where Anmol factors 20u²v - 10uv² as 10uv(2u-v).

Description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

Description: Anmol factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).

Description: Anmol shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

Title: Intro to factors & divisibility
Description: Sal explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial, and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.

Title: Missing angles with a transversal
Description: Learn how to find missing angle measurements in a figure with two parallel lines and a transversal.

Title: Figuring out missing algebraic step (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves a problem where he need to find the missing algebraic step.

Title: Worked example: Solving proportions
Description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers, too.

Title: Factoring difference of squares: shared factors
Description: Sal finds the binomial factor shared by m^2-4m-45 and 6m^2-150.

Title: Worked example: finding the missing monomial factor
Description: Sal finds the missing factor F in the factorization of -30x^5 as (-10x^3)(F).

Title: Finding area by rearranging parts (Hindi)
Description: Sometimes it helps to rearrange the parts of geometric figures to find the area. That's what we're going to do here.

Title: Determining congruent triangles
Description: Sal uses the SSS, ASA, SAS, and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.

Title: Worked example: Cube root of a negative number
Description: Learn how to find the cube root of -512.

Title: Intercepts from a table
Description: Sal finds the y-intercept of the graph of a linear function given a table of values.

Title: Finding measures using rigid transformations
Description: Rigid transformations preserve angles and distance. See how this behavior is used to find missing measures when given a triangle and the result of reflecting that triangle.

Title: Triangle angle challenge problem 2
Description: Example of angle hunting!

Title: Finding a percent
Description: Percent means per-hundred. Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

Title: Square root of decimal
Description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.

Title: Solving unit rate problem
Description: Jayda takes 3 hours to deliver newspapers on her route. What is the rate per hour at which she delivers the newspapers?

Title: x-intercept of a line
Description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards, he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.

Title: Fitting a line to data
Description: Sal creates a scatter plot and then fits a line to data on the median California family income.

Title: Determining translations
Description: Sal is given two triangles on the coordinate plane, and determines the translation that maps one of them into the other.

Title: Fraction, decimal, and percent from visual model
Description: Sal identifies the fraction, decimal, and percent represented by visual models.

Title: Frequency tables & dot plots
Description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

Title: Recognizing functions from table
Description: Checking whether a table of people and their heights can represent a function that assigns a height to a name.

Title: Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean theorem
Description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

Title: Recognizing functions from graph
Description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function, each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.

Title: Slope of a line: negative slope
Description: Sal finds the slope of a line given its graph.

Title: Systems of equations with graphing: chores
Description: Graphical Systems Application Problem

Title: Graph from slope-intercept equation
Description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form, we can use the information given by that form. For example, y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0,3). This gives us one point the line goes through, and the direction we should continue from that point to draw ...Show More

Title: Linear functions word problem: fuel
Description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

Title: Linear functions word problem: pool
Description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a pool being filled with water, and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

Title: Coordinate plane: graphing points
Description: Sal graphs ordered pairs, such as (8, 10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

Title: Graphing proportional relationships: unit rate
Description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given a unit rate.

Title: Graphing proportional relationships from a table
Description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given a table.

Title: Graphing proportional relationships from an equation
Description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given an equation.

Title: Completing solutions to 2-variable equations
Description: Given a 2-variable equation and the x or y values of a solution, Sal finds the value of the other variable in the solution.

Title: Systems of equations with graphing: 5x+3y=7 & 3x-2y=8
Description: Sal solves the system of equations 5x + 3y = 7 and 3x - 2y = 8 by graphing.

Title: Graphing a linear equation: y=2x+7
Description: Learn how to create a graph of the linear equation y = 2x + 7.

Title: Slope-intercept equation from graph
Description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

Title: Greatest common factor of monomials (Hindi)
Description: Anmol finds the greatest common factor of 10cd^2 and 25c^3d^2.

Title: Growing by a percentage
Description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.

Title: Creating a histogram
Description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram, each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: potato chips
Description: Sal solves another system of equations using elimination.

Title: How volume changes from changing dimensions
Description: Sal discusses changing dimensions on a rectangular prism affects its volume.

Title: Intro to point-slope form
Description: Point-slope is the general form y-y₁=m(x-x₁) for linear equations. It emphasizes the slope of the line and a point on the line (that is not the y-intercept). Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

Title: Identifying percent amount and base
Description: Sal identifies the percent, amount, and base in a percent problem.

Title: Identifying perfect square form (Hindi)
Description: Anmol shows how we can identify that a trinomial has the "perfect square" form.

Title: Identifying perfect square form
Description: Sal shows how we can identify that a trinomial has the "perfect square" form.

Title: Proportional relationships: graphs
Description: Learn how to tell proportional relationships by drawing graphs. Key idea: the graph of a proportional relationship is a straight line through the origin.

Title: Identifying transformations
Description: Identifying which transformation was performed between a pair of figures (translation, rotation, reflection, or dilation).

Title: Identity property of 0
Description: Sal shows how any number plus 0 is the original number.

Title: Identity property of 1
Description: The identity property of 1 says that any number multiplied by 1 keeps its identity. In other words, any number multiplied by 1 stays the same. The reason the number stays the same is because multiplying by 1 means we have 1 copy of the number. For example, 32x1=32.

Title: Impact on median & mean: increasing an outlier
Description: Sal thinks through the effects of modifying a value in a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

Title: Impact on median & mean: removing an outlier
Description: Sal thinks through the effects of removing a low outlier from a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

Title: Systems of equations number of solutions: fruit prices (1 of 2)
Description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

Title: Solutions to systems of equations: dependent vs. independent
Description: A dependent system of equations has infinite solutions, and an independent system has a single solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's dependent or independent.

Title: One-step inequality word problem
Description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.

Title: Plotting an inequality example
Description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

Title: Inequalities using addition and subtraction
Description: Inequalities Using Addition and Subtraction

Title: One-step inequalities examples
Description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!

Title: Systems of equations number of solutions: fruit prices (2 of 2)
Description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!

Title: Challenge problems: perimeter & area
Description: Three example problems involving perimeter and area.

Title: Interpreting a graph example
Description: Learn to interpret the graphs of a linear functions.

Title: Interpreting bar graphs: alligators
Description: Lindsay solves a multi-step word problem using a bar graph.

Title: Linear graphs word problem: cats
Description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

Title: Linear equations word problems: volcano
Description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

Title: Interpreting a histogram
Description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms, which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.

Title: Linear graphs word problems
Description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

Title: Interpreting plotted points (Hindi)
Description: Anmol works through a word problem interpreting coordinates in the first quadrant on a coordinate plane.

Title: Interpreting a trend line
Description: Sal interprets a trend line that shows the relationship between study time and math test score for Shira.

Title: Interpreting two-way tables
Description: Learn how to read two-way tables.

Title: Intersection and union of sets
Description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

Title: Intro to compound interest
Description: Let's understand how compound interest is different from simple interest. Let's also see how compound interest is simply a special case of percentage increase.

Title: Intro to cube roots (Hindi)
Description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

Title: Intro to direct & inverse variation (Hindi)
Description: Anmol explains what it means for quantities to vary directly or inversely, and gives many examples of both types of variation.

Title: Intro to equations with variables on both sides (Hindi)
Description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2p + 3 = 5p - 2.

Title: Intro to factors and divisibility (Hindi)
Description: Anmol explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial, and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.

Title: Intro to grouping (Hindi)
Description: Anmol introduces the method of grouping, which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

Title: Intro to Quadrilateral (Hindi)
Description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid, parallelogram, rectangle, rhombus, and square.

Title: Intro to two-step equations (Hindi)
Description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

Title: Intro to cube roots
Description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

Title: Intro to exponents
Description: Sal shows how exponents are repeated multiplication

Title: Intro to intercepts
Description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are. The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

Title: Intro to proportional relationships
Description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

Title: Intro to rational & irrational numbers
Description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

Title: Intro to slope
Description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

Title: Intro to square roots
Description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

Title: Introduction to the coordinate plane (Hindi)
Description: Introduction to the coordinate plane and plotting points on the coordinate plane.

Title: Rigid transformations intro
Description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is, what are the rigid transformations, and which transformations are not rigid.

Title: Area of a parallelogram
Description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height, just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

Title: Area of a triangle
Description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height, which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

Title: Dividing both sides of an equation
Description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.

Title: Intuitive sense of probabilities
Description: Think about what probabilities really mean. What does a probability of 0 mean? How about 1?

Title: Inverse property of addition
Description: The simple idea that a number plus its negative is 0

Title: Inverse property of multiplication
Description: Simple idea that multiplying by a number's multiplicative inverse gets you back to one. 5 × 1/5 = 1

Title: Inverse variation word problem: string vibration
Description: Sal models a context about lengths of strings and the frequency of their vibrations! with an inverse variation equation.

Title: Inverse variation word problem: string vibration (Hindi)
Description: Anmol talks about a problem that involves Force and acceleration. As per 2nd Law of Motion, Force is directly proportional to acceleration.

Title: Systems of equations with elimination: King's cupcakes
Description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

Title: Kite as geometric shape (Hindi)
Description: Anmol discusses a special type of quadrilateral, the kite.

Title: Proofs with transformations
Description: N/A

Title: Linear & nonlinear functions: word problem
Description: Learn to determine if the relationship described in a word problem is a function.

Title: Linear & nonlinear functions: missing value
Description: Learn to find the missing value in a table to make sure it represents a linear equation.

Title: Linear & nonlinear functions: table
Description: Learn to determine if a table of values represents a linear function.

Title: Two-step equation word problem: oranges
Description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video, we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41,790.

Title: Linear equation word problem: saline (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves the following word problem: You have 50 ounces of a 25% saline solution. How many ounces of a 10% saline solution must you add to make a solution that is 15% saline?

Title: Linear equation word problem: sugary drinks (Hindi)
Description: Anmol solves the following problem: Drink A with 40% sugar is mixed with Drink B to obtain Drink C which has 25% sugar. What is the percentage of sugar of Drink B?

Title: Linear Equations 2 (Hindi)
Description: Solving equations of the form AX+B=C.

Title: Linear Equations 3 (Hindi)
Description: Linear equations with multiple variable and constant terms.

Title: Slope-intercept form problems
Description: Learn how to solve problems involving writing an equation in slope-intercept form.

Title: Linear equations with unknown coefficients
Description: Sal solves the equations ax+3x=bx+5 and a(5-x)=bx-8 for x. Note that these equations include other unknowns (a and b) but we solve them for x.

Title: Linear models word problem: book
Description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

Title: Linear models word problem: marbles
Description: Sal solves a word problem about a person filling a glass tank with marbles, The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

Title: Making predictions with probability
Description: Predict the number of times a spinner will land on an elephant.

Title: Mapping shapes
Description: Finding a sequence of rigid transformations that maps one shape onto another shape.

Title: Volume of a rectangular prism: word problem
Description: Sal explains how to find the volume of a rectangular prism fish tank that has fractional side lengths.

Title: Mean, median, & mode example
Description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean, median, and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

Title: Measuring volume as area times length
Description: Sal transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area times length.

Title: Measuring volume as area times length (Hindi)
Description: Anmol transitions from measuring volume with unit cubes to multiplying area times length.

Title: Measuring volume with unit cubes
Description: Learn to measure volume of rectangular prisms with cube units.

Title: Measuring volume with unit cubes (Hindi)
Description: Learn to measure volume of rectangular prisms with cube units.

Title: Missing angles with a transversal (Hindi)
Description: Learn how to find missing angle measurements in a figure with two parallel lines and a transversal.

Title: Multiplying binomials by polynomials challenge
Description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (2x+4)(5x-9)=ax²+bx-46 true for all x-values.

Title: Figuring out missing algebraic step
Description: N/A

Title: Multiplying monomials challenge

Description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

Title: Intro to nets of polyhedra
Description: Admittedly, "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating, multi-headed fish. But in reality, nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects, like wrapping paper around presents.

Title: Number of solutions to equations (Hindi)

Title: Number of solutions to equations

Title: Creating an equation with no solutions
Description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

Description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

Title: One-step inequality involving addition
Description: One-Step Inequalities

Title: Orders of magnitude exercise example 1

Description: N/A

Title: Triangle congruence postulates/criteria
Description: Sal introduces and justifies the SSS, SAS, ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA, better to watch next video.

Title: Parallel & perpendicular lines (Hindi)
Description: Parallel lines are lines in a plane that are always the same distance apart. Parallel lines never intersect. Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right (90 degrees) angle.

Title: Partial circle area and arc length
Description: Sal finds the area of a semicircle and the arc length of a partial circle.

Title: Squaring binomials of the form (x+a)²

Title: Percents from fraction models

Description: Sal solves percent word problems including percent comparisons and percent of change.

Title: Percent word problem: recycling cans
Description: It's nice to practice conversion problems, but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

Title: Percent word problem: penguins
Description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.

Title: Perfect square factorization intro
Description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b², then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example, x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

Title: Perfect square factorization intro (Hindi)
Description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b², then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example, x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b², which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

Title: Perimeter & area
Description: Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Area measures the space inside a shape. Learn how to calculate perimeter and area for various shapes.

Title: Perimeter & area of composite shapes

Title: Perimeter and area of composite shapes (Hindi)
Description: Anmol finds perimeter and area of a non-standard polygon.

Title: Plotting corners of a rectangle (Hindi)
Description: Anmol plots the corners of a rectangle on the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

Title: Plotting inequalities
Description: To plot an inequality, such as x>3, on a number line, first draw a circle over the number (e.g., 3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤), fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <), leave the circle unfilled in. Finally, draw a line going from the circle in the direction ...Show More

Title: Graphing a linear equation: 5x+2y=20
Description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.

Title: Decimals & fractions on the number line
Description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

Title: Intro to long division of polynomials
Description: Any quotient of polynomials a(x)/b(x) can be written as q(x)+r(x)/b(x), where the degree of r(x) is less than the degree of b(x). For example, (x²-3x+5)/(x-1) can be written as x-2+3/(x-1). This latter form can be more useful for many problems that involve polynomials. The most common method for finding ...Show More

Title: Polynomial multiplication word problem (Hindi)
Description: Anmol finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.

Title: Polynomial word problem area of a window (Hindi)

Title: Polynomial word problem: rectangle and circle area (Hindi)
Description: Anmol writes a binomial to express the difference between the area of a rectangle and the area of a circle.

Title: Polynomial word problem: total value of bills (Hindi)
Description: Anmol writes a polynomial to express the total value of p twenty Rs. notes, q ten Rs. notes, and r five Rs. coins.

Title: Polynomial word problem: rectangle and circle area
Description: Sal writes a binomial to express the difference between the area of a rectangle and the area of a circle.

Title: Polynomial word problem: total value of bills
Description: Sal writes a polynomial to express the total value of p twenty dollar bills, q ten dollar bills, and r five dollar bills.

Title: Polynomials intro
Description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

Title: Polynomials intro (Hindi)
Description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ, where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example, 3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms, degree, standard form, monomial, binomial and trinomial.

Title: Positive & negative slope
Description: Sal analyzes what it means for a slope to be positive or negative (spoiler: it affects the direction of the line!)

Title: Identifying type of transformation
Description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images, and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

Title: 1 and -1 to different powers
Description: Use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression.

Title: Powers of fractions
Description: Just like whole numbers with exponents, fractions are repeatedly multiplied. If you know how to multiply fractions, you're over half way there.

Title: Powers of products & quotients (integer exponents)
Description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n, (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

Title: Powers of products & quotients integer exponents (Hindi)
Description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n, (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

Title: Powers of zero
Description: Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. Zero to any positive exponent equals zero. So, what happens when you have zero to the zero power?

Title: Comparing rates example
Description: Sal puts three fish tanks in order by volume of water per fish.

Title: Number of solutions to a system of equations graphically
Description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.

Title: Systems of equations with substitution: -3x-4y=-2 & y=2x-5
Description: Learn to solve the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.

Title: Simple probability: non-blue marble
Description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

Title: Geometry proof problem: squared circle
Description: Sal finds a missing angle using triangle congruence in a diagram that contains sector of a circle inscribed within a square.

Description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c and (a^b)^c. See WHY they work and HOW to use them.

Title: Proof: all circles are similar (Hindi)
Description: Watch Anmol informally prove that all circles are similar by showing how we can translate then dilate any circle onto another.

Title: Proof: Corresponding angle equivalence (Hindi)
Description: Proof of why corresponding angles are equal in Hindi

Title: Proof: Diagonals of a parallelogram
Description: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.

Title: Proof: Diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other (Hindi)
Description: Anmol proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.

Title: Proof: Equal opposite sides of a quad. implies gm (Hindi)
Description: Anmol proves that if a quadrilateral has opposite sides equal it means that the quadrilateral is a parallelogram.

Title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram (Hindi)
Description: Anmol proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

Title: Proof: Opposite angles of a parallelogram
Description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

Title: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram are equal (Hindi)
Description: Anmol proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

Title: Proof: Opposite sides of a parallelogram
Description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

Title: Proof: Rhombus area
Description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.

Title: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors
Description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.

Title: Proof: Rhombus diagonals are perpendicular bisectors (Hindi)
Description: Anmol proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular, and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.

Title: Angles in a triangle sum to 180° proof
Description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

Title: Proportional relationships
Description: Sal determines which ratios are proportionate to a ratio provided in a context.

Title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: fishing boat
Description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.

Title: Pythagorean theorem example
Description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

Title: Pythagorean theorem word problem: carpet
Description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

Title: Pythagorean theorem proof using similarity

Description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find a missing side length in an isosceles triangle.

Description: N/A

Title: Quadrilateral properties (Hindi)

Description: Learn to identify quadrilaterals such as kites, trapezoids, parallelograms, rhombuses, rectangles, and squares by line and angle type.

Description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle in HIndi

Description: Discover a pattern that explains why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.

Title: Reading bar graphs: Harry Potter
Description: Sal interprets a bar graph.

Title: Reading bar charts: comparing two sets of data
Description: A bar chart is especially useful with comparing two sets of data. The difference in the bars give us a quick snapshot that allows us to draw some conclusions.

Title: Reading bar charts: putting it together with central tendency
Description: Let's combine some learning! Here we looking at bar charts and using the information to determine the measures of central tendency.

Title: Reading bar graphs
Description: Reading Bar Graphs.

Title: Reading pictographs
Description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.

Description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)

Title: Recognising direct & inverse variation (Hindi)

Title: Recognising direct & inverse variation: table (Hindi)
Description: Anmol is given a table with a few values of the variables x and y, and determines whether the variables vary directly or inversely.

Title: Recognizing common 3D shapes

Title: Recognizing direct & inverse variation
Description: Sal gives many examples of two-variable equations where the variables vary directly, inversely, or neither.

Title: Recognizing divisibility
Description: Recognizing Divisibility.

Description: Checking whether y can be described as a function of x if y is always three more than twice x.

Description: Sal determines if y is a function of x from looking at a table.

Description: Checking whether a description of the price of an order can be represented as a function of the shipping cost.

Description: Learn to recognize if a function is linear.

Description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4,-2) and (0,5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

Description: Sal shows an example finding the relative complement or difference of two sets A and B.

Title: Converting percents to decimals & fractions example
Description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.

Title: Representing a relationship with an equation
Description: Equations are about relationships (no, not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.

Title: Rhombus diagonals

Description: Proof that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular bisectors of each other

Title: Rigid transformations: preserved properties

Title: Rotating 2D shapes in 3D

Title: Congruence and similarity — Basic example
Description: Watch Sal work through a basic congruence and similarity problem.

Description: See how we solve a word problem by using a scale drawing and finding the scale factor.

Title: Scientific notation examples
Description: Scientific notation is a way of writing very large or very small numbers. A number is written in scientific notation when a number between 1 and 10 is multiplied by a power of 10. For example, 650,000,000 can be written in scientific notation as 6.5 ✕ 10^8.

Title: Scientific notation word problem: U.S. national debt
Description: Ever wonder what your part of the national debt is? It might surprise you. What isn't surprising is that you can use scientific notation and division to figure out the answer.

Title: Scientific notation word problem: speed of light
Description: Amazingly, we can figure out how far the sun is from the earth if we know how to multiply numbers in scientific notation.

Title: Multiplying in scientific notation example
Description: Learn how to solve a multiplication problem using scientific notation: (9.1 * 10^6)(3.2 * 10^-5)

Title: Scientific notation examples
Description: More scientific notation examples

Title: Scientific notation example: 0.0000000003457
Description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very, very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!

Title: Introduction to scientific notation
Description: Introduction to scientific notation. An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.

Description: Determining whether segment lengths and angle measures are preserved under a given sequence of transformations.

Description: how are virtual sets built in the computer?
